# Conclusion {#sec-conclusion}

This paper documents Employee Hardship Funds, a widespread but unstudied organizational practice that blends worker mutual aid with inward-oriented CSR.  We provide the first systematic evidence on how these programs affect workers. 
Three findings stand out. First, worker awareness is modest despite strong interest. Only 23% of retail workers report awareness that their employer offers emergency cash assistance, yet when explained, workers value EHFs as highly as improved health insurance.  At Walmart, the majority of workers were unaware of this amenity. Why does a benefit workers value remain so invisible? Mechanisms could include optimism bias among workers, strategic information management by employers, or employers simply failing to recognize that more outreach is needed.

Second, realistic EHF messages can increase job attachment without improving  financial security---our central paradox. At Home Depot, exposure to Homer Fund messages significantly increased job attachment and reduced support for unionization among previously unaware workers yet had no effect on confidence in covering a $400 expense. Workers seem to respond to symbolic signals of workplace aid independent of direct material security improvements.  How do programs generate attachment without addressing the economic precarity they ostensibly target?

Third, EHF effects are context-contingent. Messages about the Home Depot's generous, heavily promoted, and culturally integrated EHF produced the expected governance effects. Walmart's less generous program in a cost-control culture produced no attachment gains and reduced opposition to unions---the opposite of presumed employer interests. With  two firms we cannot isolate the features that drive differences, but the contrast shows that program design and cultural context matter.  Like high performance work systems, inward-CSR is a bundle of practices, not an isolated intervention [@macduffieHumanResourceBundles1995; @ichniowskiEffectsHumanResource1997].

For managers, a well-designed and promoted EHF can strengthen employee attachment, but token programs risk highlighting inadequacy rather than demonstrating care.  Clearly sufficient EHF generosity to be meaningful alongside visible, multi-channel promotion are important.  Another key managerial challenge is striking the right balance between verifying actual emergency and rapid delivery of urgently needed funds.^[An executive at a third-party EHF provider bluntly stated that "I think a program with a low grant application approval rate does more harm than good to the employee-employer relationship."]  More direct worker involvement in EHF design and operation is another area for innovation, one that may contribute to a good balance between verification and speed.

For policymakers, EHFs illustrate that private welfare can supplement but not substitute for robust public social insurance. They also highlight how existing safety nets often fail to deliver during acute need. Finally, we have no evidence for whether the public benefits of EHFs justify their tax-advantaged status. Our findings suggest they function more as governance tools than as effective safety-net supplements.

Our study has important limitations. We measure only short-term attitudes, not long-term behavior.^[To investigate effect persistence, Study 3 included a pre-registered one-week follow-up survey.  We received follow up surveys from only 157 respondents (16% response rate).  The under-powered follow up survey limits our ability to draw strong conclusions; see Appendix \@ref(app-followup-wmt).]  Our samples under-represent the most precarious workers.  With two firms we can observe that effects vary across organizational contexts, but cannot pinpoint the full causal process. To make progress, future research will need to track workers longitudinally, exploit variation in EHF adoption timing, examine behavioral outcomes, and study larger samples varying systematically in program characteristics, all difficult tasks. 

The central paradox captures something fundamental about contemporary employment relationships. In precarious labor markets with weak public safety nets, gestures toward mutual aid can generate job attachment even if actual improvements to workers' economic security are fleeting or non-existent. EHFs may represent genuine assistance when public support falls short or a strategy for cultivating attachment while sustaining precarious employment. But the evidence suggests caution: the EHFs studied here function as governance tools that shape worker attitudes while delivering modest, discretionary aid. As corporations expand their role in welfare provision, understanding whether these arrangements serve worker interests or merely employer control becomes essential.

# More Background on EHFs and EHF third party providers {#app-3rd}

In 2001, the US Internal Revenue Service (IRS) amended its rules to allow employer-controlled non-profit foundations to provide direct cash assistance to employees who under certain conditions, called a "qualifying event". Funds can only be used for basic living expenses (food, clothing, transportation, housing/house repair, burial) for the recipient and immediate family [@internalrevenueserviceDisasterReliefProviding2014; @aprillCharitableClassDisaster2016]. So long as these guidelines are followed, EHFs are tax-exempt charities; donations are tax deductible.  
 
There are now multiple organizations that provide EHF outsourcing services to firms.  Beyond the Employee Assistance Foundation, I have identified E4E Relief, America's Charities, and Canary.  EAF appears to be the largest and claims to have over 400 clients [@employeeassistancefoundationDecadeAssistanceOffering2022]. 
Figure \@ref(fig:fig-tpm) illustrates the scale and growth of EHFs using data from IRS 990 forms.^[If a firm contracts with a third party to administer an EHF program, all donations and grants are linked to the third party contractor's EIN, not the original firm.  With a large number of employers offering EHFs through third party providers, we cannot systematically identify firms with and without EHFs through IRS 990 filings.] Figure \@ref(fig:fig-tpm) compares the revenues and total grants paid out to individuals from four EHF outsourcing organizations.  EAF, the oldest and largest, has grown rapidly since first appearing in IRS data in 2012, reaching over \$144 million in revenue and \$86 million in grants to individuals in 2020. The data also show the recent entry of several competitor organizations, with E4E and America's Charities operating a similar scales in recent years and Canary growing rapidly.

# Measurement {#app-measurement}

This appendix provides detailed information on all measures used in Studies 1-3, including item wording, response scales, and psychometric properties.

## Item wording and response scales for key outcome variables

### EHF Awareness (List-based measure) {#app-HFaware}

Our preferred "list-based" measure of EHF awareness comes from a question in which respondents were shown a list of eight workplace benefits and programs and asked: *"Employers sometimes create programs or offer benefits for their workers. Which of the benefits on this list are offered to workers like you at [Employer name]? Please select all that apply."*

The list varied slightly by survey:

- Paid sick days
- Paid vacation days
- Health plan or medical insurance  
- A retirement plan other than Social Security
- **Emergency cash assistance to help in unexpected hard times** [Study 1,3]/ **Cash grant to help in times of financial emergency** [Study 2]
- Paid parental leave
- Free or subsidized childcare [Study 1, 3]/Company provided or subsidized childcare [Study 2]
- Tuition discount or reimbursement for schooling [Study 1, 3]
- None of these [Study 2]

**Coding:** Respondents who selected the bolded item were coded as aware of EHF (1 = aware, 0 = not aware).

We used the list-based approach to two main reasons.  First, we wanted to avoid contaminating the experiment by priming respondents pre-treatment, so we embedded the item in a longer list and did not use the program name.  Second, this approach avoids problems with demand effects.   

To provide bounds on awareness, we asked other questions of subsets of the respondents.  In studies 2 & 3, control group respondents saw no information about the EHF in the survey.  One measure of prior EHF awareness is therefore the proportion of control group respondents who answer "yes" to a direct question about whether their employer has an EHF. In Study 2, we asked control group respondents only the following: 
> "Some companies have programs that take donations and provide emergency cash to help workers like you through hard times. Does The Home Depot offer a program like this for workers like you?"  

On this basis, I estimate the weighted proportion of Home Depot control-condition respondents who report knowing about the EHF as `r round(aware_tab$aware.prop.s,2)` (se = `r round(aware_tab$aware.prop.s_se,2)`).  The difference in estimated awareness produced by the this measure of awareness and the list approach used in the main text is striking.  Among those in the control group correctly answering "yes" to the direct question about their employer's EHF, `r round(100*aware_xt["FALSE","Yes"]/sum(aware_xt[,"Yes"]),0)`% _failed_ to identify the cash grant program as one of their job benefits whereas nearly all of those correctly choosing the cash grant program from the list of benefits also correctly answered direct question.  Consequently, I interpret the lower estimate based on the "list" question as the more accurate reflection of EHF awareness.  Using the list measure of awareness, we estimate that 58% of the Home Depot sample control condition respondents are aware.  This suggested that the direct questions capture vague awareness, possibly combined with some demand effects, rather than functional understanding of the program.

In Study 3, we refined the question ordering such that we asked all respondents the direct questions about whether Walmart has an EHF.  We were careful to implement this question after the survey experiment and answers to key outcome questions.  As shown in Appendix \@ref(app:app-manip-wmt), both correctly answering the list-based awareness question and video treatment are strongly predictive of a correct answer in the direct question, as expected.  For comparability to Study 2, in Study 3  among those in the control group correctly answering "yes" to the direct question about their employer's EHF, `r round(100*aware_wmt_xt["FALSE","Yes"]/sum(aware_wmt_xt[,"Yes"]),0)`% _failed_ to identify the cash grant program as one of their job amenities.  Of those recorded as "pre-exposed", `r round(100*sum(aware_wmt_cntrl_xt["TRUE","Yes"])/sum(aware_wmt_cntrl_xt["TRUE",]))`% correctly answered yes to the direct question and `r round(100*sum(aware_wmt_cntrl_xt["TRUE","No"])/sum(aware_wmt_cntrl_xt["TRUE",]))` incorrectly answered "no", with the balance saying they were not sure (a response option not available to the control respondents in Study 2).


### EHF engagement
The EHF engagement questions were asked of different subsets of the of respondents in Study 2 and 3, based on question ordering and a desire to avoid any contamination of the experiment.

*"Do you know someone personally who has received money from [EHF name]?* 

*"Have you ever applied to the [EHF name] for financial assistance?"* 

*"Have you ever received financial assistance from the [EHF name]?"*

*"Have you ever made a donation to the [EHF name]"*

Response scale:  Yes, No, Don't know

In Study 2, the "know beneficiary" and "applied" questions were only presented to treated respondents.  The donate and grant receipt question were asked of all respondents (post treatment).  In these latter two questions, rates of reported donation and receipt were nearly identical among the treated and control groups.   

Study 3 differed from Study 2 in that we asked all Walmart respondents (not just control respondents) whether their employer has an EHF (post-treatment).  Those incorrectly answering "No" were _not_ shown the EHF engagement questions.  Thus the subset of respondents reporting EHF engagement differs somewhat between Studies 2 and 3.  Nevertheless, restricting the Study 2 sample to only treated respondents produces nearly quantities to those reported in the main text.  

### Financial Security

*"How confident are you that you could come up with $400 if an unexpected need arose within the next month?"*

Response scale:

1. I am certain I could not come up with \$400
2. I could probably not come up with \$400
3. I could probably come up with \$400
4. I am certain I could come up with the full \$400

This item is taken from the Federal Reserve Board's Survey of Household Economics and Decision-making (SHED), where it has been used since 2013 to track financial fragility [@groverWhat400Emergency2021]. The \$400 threshold reflects realistic emergency expenses for low-wage workers and has become a standard benchmark in research on financial precarity.  This particular item correlates strongly with self-reported financial indicators such as bank account balances, debt levels, and employment shocks [@boardofgovernorsofthefederalreservesystemEconomicWellBeingHouseholds2023]. 

As a second indicator, Study 2 included the question, with responses "Not at all difficult", "Somewhat difficult", "Very difficult".

### Loyalty to coworkers and employer

*"How much loyalty would you say you feel toward other workers at [Employer]?"*

*"How much loyalty would you say you feel toward [Employer] as a company?"*

Response scale:

1. No loyalty at all
2. Only a little loyalty
3. Some loyalty
4. A lot of loyalty

Both loyalty questions are taken from @freemanWorkerRepresentationParticipation1998 and analyzed in @freemanSharedCapitalismWork2010.

### Willingness to Recommend Employer

*"If a friend asked you about working at [Employer] doing a job like yours, how likely is it that you would recommend [Employer] as a place to work?"*

Response scale:

1. Definitely would not recommend
2. Might not recommend
3. Not sure
4. Might recommend
5. Certainly would recommend

This item is adapted from the Net Promoter Score (NPS) methodology commonly used in customer and worker satisfaction research.

### Quit Intentions (Study 3 only)

*"Taking everything into consideration, how likely is it you will make a genuine effort to find a new job within the next 3 months?"*

Response scale:

1. Not at all likely
2. Not very likely
3. Somewhat likely
4. Very likely
5. Extremely likely

This item is the core quit intentions question used in the SHIFT Project [@schneiderWhatFacebookTool2019]. Note this item is reverse-scaled relative to other job attachment index questions.

### Union Vote Intention

*"If an election were held today to decide whether employees like you should be represented by a union at [EMPLOYER], would you vote for the union or against the union?"*

Response scale:

- For the union
- Against the union
- Not sure

This is the standard question used in research on support for unionization at work, with a long history in industrial relations research (see @kochanWorkerVoiceAmerica2019a, @ahlquistRiseUnionCurious2024, @freemanWhatUnions1984).  Vote intention is a concrete behavioral intention, not an abstract attitude. The question reflects the union certification voting process in the US, giving it strong face validity.

### Expected Coworker Union Support (Study 3 only)

*"If an election were held today to decide whether employees like you should be represented by a union at [Employer], what percent of your co-workers do you think would vote for the union?"*

Response scale: Open numeric response from 0 to 100.

## Job attachement index construction and reliability {#app-attachmentindex}

Our goal with the job attachment index is not to argue for a novel psychological concept and propose a measurement scale. Rather we seek to provide a coherent and concise indicator of affective attachment to a particular job, encompassing both horizontal ties to coworkers and vertical ties to the employer.  

There are multiple validated indices purporting to measure "organizational identification", "organizational commitment", "organizational citizenship", and related concepts and sub-scales [@oreillyOrganizationalCommitmentPsychological1986; @zhaoInfluenceCorporateSocial2022; @mowdayOrganizationalCommitmentQuestionnaire1979; @meyerOrganizationalCommitmentScales1993].  As we had limited survey space, multiple research goals, and limited prior information, we elected not to implement any of these detailed and lengthy instruments designed to measure concepts only loosely connected to our research goals. Instead we focus a few items with strong face validity and history of use in other surveys. 

We constructed a job attachment index from items measuring loyalty to coworkers, loyalty to employer, and willingness to recommend employer. In Study 3, we also included quit intentions (reverse-coded).

### Exploratory Factor Analysis

For both Studies 2 and 3, we conducted exploratory factor analysis on the index components.  In both cases, I use minimum residual factoring methods and the oblimin rotation.  As there are many criteria for selecting factor solutions, we look at the preferred solution across multiple different criteria [@ludeckeExtractingComputingExploring2020].  In both cases, a single factor solution is preferred.

#### Home Depot {#app-HFattachment}

```{r fig-fa-plot-thd, eval=TRUE, echo=FALSE, out.width = "60%", fig.align='center'}
thd.jai.df<- THD_comp_uw[,c("wrk_loyal_num", "emp_loyal_num", "emp_reco_num")]
nf.thd <- parameters::n_factors(thd.jai.df)
plot(nf.thd)
```

```{r tab-fa-thd, eval=TRUE, echo=FALSE, results='asis'}

fa.thd<-parameters::factor_analysis(thd.jai.df)
fa.thd.tab <- fa.thd |> 
  kable(

    booktabs = TRUE,
  digits = 2,
  col.names = c("Variable", "Loading", "Complexity", "Uniqueness"),
  caption = "Factor loadings and uniqueness from one-factor solution, Home Depot (study 2)"
)

fa.thd.tab

```

A single factor explains `r round(100*summary(fa.thd)$MR1[2])`% of the variance.  All items load substantively on the first factor (loadings >.60).

#### Walmart {#app-indexcomps-wmt}

### Internal consistency \& reliability
```{r tab-alpha-calc, eval=TRUE, results='asis'}
# Study 2
alpha_thd <- psych::alpha(thd.jai.df, check.keys=TRUE)
alpha_value_s2 <- alpha_thd$total$std.alpha
mean_r_s2 <- alpha_thd$total$average_r

# Study 3
alpha_wmt <- psych::alpha(wmt.jai.df, check.keys=TRUE)
alpha_value_s3 <- alpha_wmt$total$std.alpha
mean_r_s3 <- alpha_wmt$total$average_r

reliability_table <- data.frame(
  Sample = c("Study 2 (Home Depot)", "Study 3 (Walmart)"),
  Items = c("3 items", "4 items"),
  N = c(515, 980),
  Alpha = c(alpha_thd$total$std.alpha, alpha_wmt$total$std.alpha),
  Mean_inter_item_r = c(mean_r_s2, mean_r_s3)
)

kable(reliability_table,
      caption = "Cronbach's Alpha for Job Attachment Index",
      col.names = c("Sample", "Items", "N", "alpha", "Mean inter-item r"),
      digits = 2,
      booktabs = TRUE) %>%
  kable_styling(latex_options = c("hold_position"))
```

Reliability is good in both samples ($\alpha > .70$) as is inter-item correlations (in the .50 range), supporting the use of a composite index.  The factor structure across the Walmart and Home Depot samples appear quite similar in both loadings and variance explained. Both show a single dominant factor with comparable reliability.  Raw correlations between index items as well as other outcome variables appear in Appendices \@ref(app-survsum-uw) and \@ref(app-wmt-survsum).

## Correctly responding that Walmart has an EHF
In the Walmart sample, treatment significantly increased the probability that a respondent would correctly state that Walmart has an EHF. Note that the pre-exposed were much more likely to correctly identify that Walmart has an EHF.

## Donation behavior (Walmart) {#app-donate-wmt}

```{r, results = 'asis'}
temp<-here::here('2_code', 'Walmart', '14_donate_models_WMT.R')
source(temp)
rm(temp)
```

At the end of Study 3, respondents had the opportunity to click on a link to take them to a page where they could donate to the ACNT. Based on past research [@andreoniPowerAskingHow2011], we expect those exposed to the emotional appeal in the video to be more willing to donate.  

In the Walmart sample, we see a low baseline willingness to click on the link of `r round(100*donation_summary$prop[1])`%.  Nevertheless, those seeing the EHF video were about 4 percentage points more likely to take an action to donate. Table \@ref(tab:tab-donate-models-wmt-app) presents regression-based estimates of treatment effects, using OLS and logistic regression.  We also include Firth regression to address concerns with rare events.  Treatment significantly increases willingness to take an action to donate.

# Charity and Solidarity framing experiment effects on union vote and expected co-worker union support (Walmart) {#app-framing}

```{r echo = FALSE, tab.cap = "MNL on union vote, accounting for framing experiment (Walmart)", results= 'asis'}
modelsummary(uv_wmt_mnl_frame,
             gof_map = gm,
             shape = term + response ~ statistic,
             title = "MNL on union vote, accounting for framing experiment (Walmart) \\label{tab:tab-app-mnl-framing-wmt}",
             notes = "Reference category is 'for the union.' Standard errors in parentheses",
             output = "kableExtra",
             stars = c('$^+$'=.1,'*' = .05, '**' = .01),
             threeparttable=TRUE,
             escape = TRUE
             
             )

coefs <- coef(uv_wmt_mnl_frame)
vcov_matrix <- vcov(uv_wmt_mnl_frame)

# Calculate the difference between coefficients
diff_against <- coefs[1, "treatment_framing_refcharity"] - coefs[1, "treatment_framing_refsolidarity"]
diff_ns <- coefs[2, "treatment_framing_refcharity"] - coefs[2, "treatment_framing_refsolidarity"]

# Standard error of the difference
se_diff_against <- sqrt(
  diag(vcov_matrix)["Against the union:treatment_framing_refcharity"] + 
    diag(vcov_matrix)["Against the union:treatment_framing_refsolidarity"] - 
    2 * vcov_matrix["Against the union:treatment_framing_refcharity", "Against the union:treatment_framing_refsolidarity"]
)

se_diff_ns <- sqrt(
  diag(vcov_matrix)["Not sure:treatment_framing_refcharity"] + 
    diag(vcov_matrix)["Not sure:treatment_framing_refsolidarity"] - 
    2 * vcov_matrix["Not sure:treatment_framing_refcharity", "Not sure:treatment_framing_refsolidarity"]
)


# Wald statistic (z-value) for the difference
z_against <- as.numeric(diff_against / se_diff_against)
z_ns <- as.numeric(diff_ns / se_diff_ns)
# p-value for the Wald test
p_against <- 2 * (1 - pnorm(abs(z_against)))
p_ns <- 2 * (1 - pnorm(abs(z_ns)))

Zs <- c(z_against, z_ns)
Ps <- c(p_against, p_ns)

# Display the results
test.results <- data.frame(
  Option = c("Against the union", "Not sure"),
  Z_value = Zs,
  P_value = Ps
)

# Create a nicely formatted table with kableExtra
kable(test.results, digits = 3, caption = "Testing the null that the charity and solidarity treatment effects are equal") %>%
  kableExtra::kable_styling(bootstrap_options = "striped", full_width = FALSE)

```

# Follow-up survey (Walmart) {#app-followup-wmt}

We sent an email invitation to a followup survey to all Walmart survey respondents who provided an email.  In the end, we received `r sum(!is.na(wmt.hq$age_f))` or `r round(100*sum(!is.na(wmt.hq$age_f)) /nrow(wmt.hq))`% of those completing the main survey.

Table \@ref(tab:tab-fu-wmt) reports logistic regression estimates of selection into the followup survey based on binary and full treatment status in the main survey. There is no evidence the treatment in the main survey affected selection into the followup.

```{r tab-fu-wmt, echo = FALSE, tab.cap = "Logit regression of selection into followup", results= 'asis'}
temp<-here::here('2_code', 'Walmart', '16_followup_models_WMT.R')
source(temp)
rm(temp)

logit_tab_followup
```


In Table \@ref(tab:tab-uv-models-fu-wmt),  I report mutinomial logistic regression results for the union support question, the only outcome included in the follow up for which there was a detectable treatment effect in the main survey.   The base model compares the union vote outcomes for respondents in the followup survey based on their treatment status in the original survey.  The second model reports the same model employing stabilized IPW weights, as pre-registered.^[IPW weights were calculated using a full treatment $\times$ covariate interaction logistic regression.]  In neither case is there any detectable effect one week later, but small samples combined with the sensitivity of point estimates to the IPW weights suggests that the followup survey is too under-powered for any strong conclusions to be drawn.
